captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

MIKE MUSTO: What if I told you
that bigger wasn't always

better, that bringing a knife
to a gunfight can sometimes

have advantages, and that that
old adage of "talk softly and

carry a big stick" is one of
those rare and beautiful

quotes that you can
live your life by.

Mike Maier of Maier Racing is
not an overly large man.
He's not 6' 5".

He doesn't weigh in
at 300 pounds.

And he's about as soft
spoken as they come--

that is, of course, when you're
not talking about cars.

You see, Mike is a guy that
doesn't really care about a
car's bling factor.

Get the man talking about how
to set up a car, though, and

how to make it go around a
corner at speed, and you'll

soon realize that this
mild-mannered man with the

little blue Mustang has the
ability to crush any

professionalism you might have
and make you make sounds like,
well, this.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: How do you
not love this car?
My name is Mike Musto.

Each week I travel the country
with the goal of showcasing

the best and baddest muscle
cars and hot rods around.

Every car has a past and
every owner a story.

Welcome to the world
of "Big Muscle."
[MUSIC PLAYING.
CAR ENGINES REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: Sometimes on "Big
Muscle," we're fortunate

enough to come across a car that
we don't hear about but
we see in person.

Mike Maier of Maier Racing,
his '66 Mustang
Coupe is such a car.

I've seen a lot of pro-touring
cars run at different events.

And while always impressive,
there's one or two that

usually you'll look at, and
you'll be like, I'd kind of
like to see that.

This one, however, really
kind of hit me.

I'd also seen this car run at
the Optima Ultimate Street Car
Challenge in 2011.

I decided, well,
you know what?

I'm going to give him a call and
see if he's interested in
being on the show.

So first off, he
was interested.

Second of all, I was allowed
to drive this
thing, which is fantastic.

But what I came to find out is
not only is Mike one of the

nicest guys in the hobby, but
he's a true enthusiast that

cares about one thing,
winning.

Everything Maier Racing builds
is about winning.
It's about doing it right.

This is not some big parts house
shop that goes out and

says, we're going to order parts
from here and do this,

and we're going to order
parts from there.

They make everything in house,
which nobody does anymore

because, honestly, nobody really
can anymore because
they don't have the talent.

However, when you have 70 years
of racing experience

behind you, that lets you
learn a few things.

MIKE MAIER: My dad started
it in '69.

And he Trans-Am raced
from '69 until '91.

And he did everything from
engine mods, transmissions,

rear ends, suspension,
fiberglass, posters,
emblems, oil pans.

We did everything,
only Mustangs.

So we do make pretty much
everything here, with the
exception of a few items.

So if a part doesn't
fit, that was us.

If it does fit, hey,
that was us.

So the fiberglass, we
hand lay everything.

Any carbon fiber work,
we do it all here.
Molds, here.
Plugs, here.

Suspension, fixtures,
everything, here.

This car here, my dad
bought in '83, '84.

It was a '79 four cylinder
burnt orange pile.

He made it into one of the very
first of what I would
call pro-touring cars.
He put a wide body kit on it.

It had 15-10s in the back,
15-8s in the front.

Back in the day, that
was pretty fat.

It had a 351 Windsor
with Webers.
It had a top-loader.

They came with these cruddy
old little three-speed

overdrives back in
the early '80s.

He put a 9-inch with a
Detroit Locker in it.

He put big rear drums, big
discs in the front.

This car was a bad machine
in the '80s.

And I drove it a little bit,
and I really ruined it.
I just hacked on it.
And I cut it up.

And I did a lot of really
stupid things to it.

And I ended up really
cutting it up.

One day, I stripped every
panel off the thing.
I pulled the motor.
I bought a suspension.

It wasn't what I was
thinking it was.

So this was the first car
I did suspension on
wholeheartedly.

I made my own struts
with a good friend
of mine, Guy Ankeny.
He mainly did it.
I made my own rear suspension.
I did my cage.

That is the very first main
hoop I ever put in a car.

We've ended up winning Nationals
with this car
several times now.
We've won a pile of races.

And this is the village
bicycle.

We just drive the
snot out of it.
And it's evolved to this.

It's one of the fastest
cars in the nation.
MIKE MUSTO: All right.

So standing next to
me is Mike Maier.

And we're talking about
your '66 Mustang.

Now, when I was at the Good
Guys Show, I was kind of

enamored with the fact
that you just kind
of destroyed everybody.

But then when I walked by the
car, the trunk was open, and

that's what really
caught my eye.

So could you explain to me about
the suspension under
here and how you developed it?
MIKE MAIER: Sure.
MIKE MUSTO: Cool.
So what do we got under here?

Because this is one of the
trickest systems I
think I've ever seen.

MIKE MAIER: Well, basically
when we designed the

suspension, we wanted
to be able to drive
the car on the road.

And if we put the coil-overs
under the floor, the shocks

and springs under the floor,
we didn't think we'd have

enough travel to hit
train tracks with a
coffee in your hand.

So there just wasn't
enough room.

So if we move them into the
trunk, we can have all the

room we wanted to have a big
stroke of shock and all that
good stuff.

So we can hit bumps and not
pack out the shocks.

MIKE MUSTO: So it was really all
about functionality, then.

MIKE MAIER: Yeah, we
just wanted to
drive the car initially.

It had nothing to
do with racing.
MIKE MUSTO: OK.

MIKE MAIER: And then we stumbled
upon the geometry and

everything that went
along with it.

So when we got into that, all
of a sudden we started

noticing all the benefits and
all the things that we could
do with it.
And it just grew from there.

MIKE MUSTO: So let's move to the
front of the car, and just

give me an idea of-- we
obviously know the back is
pretty trick.

Let's see what's
done up front.

MIKE MAIER: Contrary to belief
in the back, I really think

that suspension needs
to be simple.
MIKE MUSTO: OK.

MIKE MAIER: We really focused
on making sure the control
arms were the right geometry.

Geometry's kind of the heart of
your suspension, the angles
and all that stuff.

Then what compliments it is
the spring and the shock.

If you don't put good icing on
the cake, nobody's really

going to be thinking
about the cake.
MIKE MUSTO: OK.

MIKE MAIER: So we bought
basically the best
shocks you can buy.
We got JRi shocks.

We're running a great
hypercoil spring.

But the big thing with that is
it just allows the geometry to
be accentuated.

You need to be able to control
it with all that.

So we didn't go bonkers
up here.

We just kept it simple and
really good and clean.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: Power-wise, we're
talking about a 302 with about

300 horsepower, four-speed
top loader.

It's carbureted and
it really is good.
I mean, you can see.

You roll into it, we've
got the power.

We've got the brakes
to throw it in.

They're manual brakes, Wilwood
calipers, but the handling on
this car is truly sublime.
It's quick-steering.

You can pinch it
in, hammer out.
The car's not going to skip.
It's not going to move.

What you have to do is
you have to trust it.

You've got to trust it to
throw into the corner.
Feel the tires bite.
Hammer out.
Put your foot on the gas.
I mean, just--
it's fun.

This is a slot car
for the street.
I can see why Mike wins.

Most '66 Mustangs, if you've
ever driven one in stock
condition, they're sloppy.

You have all that play
in the steering.

You have all that play
in the suspension.
Because that's what it was.

Mike's managed to take this
car and really do special

things with it, to the point
where I'm on a back road.

I want to take this
on the track.

I want to take this on the
autocross, and I want to line
this sucker out.

The car tells you, drive
me at ten-tenths.
You know what I mean?

Let me do what I was
built to do.

Now, unfortunately we can only
experience a little of that

today because we're
on public roads.

But I can tell you, because I've
been driving cars for a

long time, both on the racetrack
and on the street,
that this car is well built.

And the stuff that these guys
preach, take it to heart,
because it's true.

MIKE MAIER: Basically,
predicting what the market
wants, it's a crap shoot.

When the Eleanor thing came
through, the movie happened.
It just happened.

And all of a sudden, everybody's
calling you
wanting parts.

That was a huge help
to our company.

The pro-touring scene,
I think it was great.

People got tired of just looking
at their car with
these big balloon tires.
They wanted to wheel it.
They wanted to drive it.
Well, we were already driving.
We'd been doing that.

So a good friend of ours, Brian,
said, Mike, you've got

to take your Mustang
out and wheel it.

And that's how we got
started in it.

But what I basically figured out
with predicting the market
was, to hell with the market.
Do whatever you do good.

And if you do something good
and it's worth attention,
it'll bring it.

And if it's not, then,
well, you're ass out.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: One of the cool
parts about first talking to

Mike is Mike is not a
self-promoter by any means.

You know, a lot of these guys
you'll speak to, and it's, me,

me, me, my business, my
business, we're better than

the next guy, and you'll
constantly hear competitors--

hey, thanks for pulling
over, Mr. Volvo.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
[BEEP]

MIKE MUSTO: Basically what he
does is he just shows up,
wins, and goes home.

And then he lets people kind
of go, what just happened?

Why did I lose when I just spent
all this money on a car?

Well, you lost because there
are other guys out
there doing it better.
They don't need to talk.
They just need to do.
These are the doers.

If you go out and you build
stuff that is this good and

that can compete with their
stuff, you let me know.
Right now, I haven't found it.

This car is fantastic,
and it's fun.
I want to go to a track!
Oh, I want to go to a track.

MIKE MAIER: My excitement is
getting dirty, laying on the
ground, racing.

I look back, I'm a little
irritated about missing the

days when you could wear
the bubble glasses, the

half-helmet, and you get out
and your face is all dirty

because you were running a Lola,
and you had a big block
strapped to your back.
I wish I had that day.

And I wish it was now, and it
was current, and it was real
competition.

I think, the new stuff,
hey, I'll wheel it.
I'll drive it.
I'll set it up.

But I think if there was a time
that fit me the best, it
was Can-Am.

It was the old indie cars where
you'd put it into a wall

and you wouldn't
come out alive.

And this just matches
my style better.

MIKE MUSTO: You know, I wasn't
familiar with Maier Racing up

until, I'll be honest,
quite recently.

But it wasn't because of
their advertising.
It wasn't because of banners.

And it wasn't because
of fanfare.

It was because I went to a
car show, and I saw one
of their cars run.

And I was so intrigued by how
well it did that I made it my

business to find out who they
were and what they did.

A lot of people will take their
product, and they'll
throw it in your face.

And they'll say,
we're the best.
We're the greatest.
You need to buy our stuff.

When a lot of times, what you
really need to do is shut up

and turn the internet off
because, at the end of the

day, it's the quiet ones that
you really should be paying
attention to.

MIKE MAIER: But this package
here was just something
sitting in the shop.

Over a couple of years, we
sat there and said--
MIKE MUSTO: [LAUGHS]
You said, get the [BLEEP]
out of my face, fly.
That's what we said.

MIKE MAIER: That thing's
getting right there.
MIKE MUSTO: [LAUGHS]
MIKE MAIER: You saw it, too.

MIKE MUSTO: Yeah, because
it was like--
[LAUGHTER]

MIKE MAIER: I feel
like an elephant.

MIKE MUSTO: Welcome
to "Big Muscle."

title: Maier Racing Mustang: More grip than a GT3? - /BIG MUSCLE

hovering over the pedal. maybe just barely touching it. No pressure on 
anything.
comments.author: yamahondarider

comments.text:
+yamahondarider Yap, they have an ich or so before engaging the clutch, but 
the bearing is not resting.
As soon as you place the foot on the pedal, under half an inch is enough, 
then the bearing starts to rotate.
Left foot on footrest between every clutching.   This is one of the first 
things to learn when starting driving.  :)
comments.author: Nordmore68

comments.text:
+Nordmore68 hes not putting pressure on it. Just has it ready to change 
gear. If you are shifting often its much easier to keep your foot above the 
pedal than swing it up from next to it and back to the floor and back onto 
it and then back next to it. Most pedals have an inch or so of travel 
before you even begin to engage the clutch.

I have been watching Mike Maier autox C Prepared Mustangs for many, many 
years at the SCCA Solo Nationals.  He has just won yet again at the Lincoln 
Solo Nationals a couple of weeks ago.  For the first time ever I was 
fortunate to be sitting in a grid spot right behind him.  While we were 
using ice and water sprayer to cool down our Avon A15's, Mike was using 
cold wet towels out of an ice chest and left them on the tires until it was 
time to run again - great idea.  I am glad that Mike is getting the 
attention that he deserves.

Jim
E Mod Yellow Jeep﻿

It's what makes the car exciting to drive at the limit. Also, Mike Maier 
likes to keep it simple, and live axles are pretty simple ;)
comments.author: Jacinth Gudetti

comments.text:
+cybertree i think you still need to work on your understanding, but you're 
getting there.
Primary advantages of a non-independent (beam) rear axle are cheapness, 
simplicity and the rear tyres are always at 0 degrees camber, with the 
tread widths being approximately evenly loaded at all times on flat 
surfaces. Disadvantage is unsprung weight and bumps affecting both tyres - 
but this actually happens with IRS as they are not truely independent.
Main advantage of IRS is reduced unsprung weight, which should allow the 
tyres to follow road irregularities better. main disadvantages is the 
linkage geometry can be a lot more difficult to work out and is more 
complex to fit in the vehicle.
With smooth road/track surfaces, the beam axle can do a very good job, 
potentially better than any IRS setup.
Axle tramp can be caused by a variety of factors, from spring windup, too 
compliant bushings, poor traction characteristics of the vehicle, etc. 
heck, as with a beam axle you need to control a lot more mass, it can ba 
argued that an IRS 'should' be better (I suspect the insulating bushings of 
the diff carrier would be a significant factor). The higher tier drag cars 
use no suspension whatsoever, with the axles being fixed to the chassis but 
they have huge problems with wheel tramp/tyre shake.
There is an intermediate design, the De Dion, which uses a chassis mounted 
differential but the two wheels are connected together with a structure - 
this isolated the suspension from the torque reaction (wedge) that a 
conventional beam axle would have, but allows the same basic geometry and 
packaging of the beam axle.
The latest Mustangs are built with IRS - must be a good reason for FORD to 
spend the additional cost of developing that and adding it to the sticker 
price...

Regardless, if it works, it works :-)
comments.author: GordonWG1

comments.text:
The live axle was abolished because it couldn't turn & handle as well as 
IRS set ups. Here's a live axle that out handles the most advanced IRS (GT3 
Porsche) while being able to handle as much power as you can throw at it.
comments.author: DirtDude117

comments.text:
Your a very sensible guy, I'm sorry my fellow American rednecks are 
attacking you with their "overwhelming knowledge" in the most mature way. 
IRS is better for Rallying and grip PERIOD, I have learned from an expert 
ancient engineer though, that in some cases (when the car has a near 
double-wishbone susp., and is almost always used on smoother track like 
conditions), a rear live axle can deliver a more "solid" handling vehicle, 
it's a gyroscopic effect that's had to describe without a moving model, 
however *SOME F1 RACERS TRUST A REAR LIVE AXLE* due to it's relentless 
power delivery, and most importantly how the tires stay at the perfect 
"power angle", a good way to imagine this effect is the exact same reason 
drag racers have larger rear wheels than the front ones, IRS's are almost 
always flexing and delivering power at the "less than perfect angle" (if 
that makes any sense), it's almost like while your in a hard turn, the 
wheel that get's most of the torque is being angled upwards so-as to cause 
more slip, this IS best for ultimate grip like I said...period, however it 
also promotes understeer, and if your a driver who prefers taking the 
chance with oversteer for that little extra boost and unrelenting torque 
and speed, in THEORY, if your a perfect driver, the live axle will always 
win, the problem is, in reality not everyone is a near perfect driver, and 
IRS's are simply easier, and more guaranteed to grip when needed. *I think 
why this vehicle (particularly) is better off with a live axle is because 
THE SUSPENSION IS DOING ALL OF THE GRIP WORK.* For a 300hp mustang, a 
double wishbone style suspension like that can basically "ignore" what the 
tires are doing because it has such a far travel that with the stang's 
power, it nearly can't outdo the suspension with HP. *SO, if the tires are 
ALWAYS being mashed to the ground by that amazing suspension, wouldn't you 
want the power/torque delivery to be at it's most consistent/relentless 
delivery? The IRS would basically be doing nothing except putting more 
stress on one tire that doesn't really need it, rather than lettting the 
engine disperse it evenly throughout both wheels, and allowing the 
suspension to worry about it's own problem.* I really hope this made sense, 
and didn't seem obnoxious (I did use caps, but for emphasis, and typed up 
half a book, my bad lmao.), because I completely agree that 90% of the 
time, an IRS can't be beat, ESPECIALLY if your looking for ultimate grip. 
But I've driven both types more times than I can remember, and 
occasionally, when the power and suspension are nicely balanced, a rear 
live axle just FEELS GOOD. It feels like your have complete control over 
both the front and the rear of the vehicle, which in the right hands, is 
WAAAY better than a vehicle that you can just floor and wait for your front 
tires to give and oversteer. Some people prefer to have the best all around 
grip balance and the occasional oversteer, some people feel more 
comfortable controlling the oversteer, and knowing THEY are in full solid 
control of the rear of the vehicle (which, again, ONLY works if you have a 
good suspension/weight balance), if a computer were driving both methods, 
the live rear axle would have the torque/horsepower boost, and would come 
out of the corner with just a little extra torque, however for humans who 
make mistakes, and for roads that suck at grip, IRS cannot be beat, it's 
more forgiving and consistent.
This page explains it better LOL. 
http://www.f1technical.net/forum/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=9491
comments.author: cybertree

comments.text:
+Bobby Navarro Which is not something I've ever heard, but I'm well versed

comments.author: Richard Harrold

comments.author: Richard Harrold

comments.text:
+Richard Harrold Yessir, no problemo. I was just really embarrassed by what 
he wrote. About live axles, my '96 Firebird Formula has one and on a 
*smooth* back road with sweeping turns, the car can really carry an 
impressive pace. It rivals what my 928 could do. The axle remains quite 
composed on most surfaces. 

However, on a tight, bumpy European back road, I'm sure I'd be left in the 
dust by a ~115 hp Pug 205
comments.author: TheNormalberries

comments.text:
Enjoy the fun and experience of a live axle vs a true IRS. If you have IRS 
,then take that to limit and enjoy.. If you have both then you know what I 
mean.They both have there fun.
comments.author: Tony T

comments.text:
+TheNormalberries Thanks... I don't see all Americans as retarded by any 
means. Yeah, we see the negative stereotypes, but that's no more true of 
the majority, I'm sure, than is the American view of the British as 
afternoon-tea-drinking snobs with bad teeth... America has produced some 
great engineering over the years, and, while I don't get live axles or 
Mustangs in general, there is no doubt that the workmanship shown in this 
build is simply exsquisite.
comments.author: Richard Harrold

comments.text:
Cool car but, "more grip than a GT3?" Not sure why that's in the title 
considering they never even talk about it... ﻿
comments.author: WesSites

comments.text:
+Brian Tracy Yes, but they never discussed its actual lateral grip, 
therefor they did not refer to the title at any point in the video. And the 
911's rear weight bias is what gives it so much rear grip... Also Porsche 
is not in any way transitioning to the Cayman or Boxster, Porsche CEO has 
even come out and said that the Cayman and Boxster will not be allowed to 
surpass the 911 because it is their Flagship car. Besides the Mustang also 
has a weight bias, one at the front which causes under-steer. I would take 
an over-steer prone car over under-steer prone any day of the week. As long 
as you don't let off the throttle prematurely then the lift off over-steer 
of the 911is not an issue. The rear wheel steer of the GT3 as well as other 
chassis magic that Porsche has been performing on their rear engine wonder 
has made it one of the best handling cars of all time, the Mustang on the 
other hand has no such accolades, it is simply fast in a straight line. 
This Mustang is a special case however and it appears to be a riot to 
drive, but again they did not provide any insight into the proposed 
question, "More grip than a GT3?".
comments.author: WesSites

comments.text:
+WesSites I can believe it .... both cars have suspensions that work WELL , 
but the Mustang (this one at least) is obviously lighter and has really 
sticky tires... Porsche , despite 50 years of development still has a 
balance problem with the rear engine ,,, back in the 70's and 80's it was 
common to see 914/6's and 916's beat up 911's at the 24 hours of Daytona... 
Today that would be the Cayman and Boxster... Porsche seems to be 
transitioning to the Cayman platform for the really hot rides....
comments.author: Brian Tracy

comments.text:
This isn't a even Mustang any longer. As he has told at 8:30 the original

suspension on a muscle car to compete on the track and that's why i can't 
take stock muscle cars serious.﻿

comments.text:
+JedinioSlobodnoIme I would rather see a muscle car that handles like a 
race car over a European or Japanese car. How many old muscle cars can take

one, It's f*cking cool. Lots of people think that old muscle cars were big 
V8, loud and handled like shit, and most of them did (in my opinion). When 
you have an old muscle car taking corners faster than a Bmw, or a japanese 
car I think that's cooler than watching a Bmw taking corners. (btw I am 
European, and I do own a Bmw too, so don't think I'm all about America, or

comments.author: Howard Schaefer

comments.text:
+JedinioSlobodnoIme
If you look at Shelby's Terligua Trans Am Mustangs from the 60's....the 
only thing that's different with Mike Maiers car is the front valence  
which is just a slightly different variation of the original Terlingua 
Mustangs with the oval valence opening.  They also removed the front 
bumpers on those cars.  The hood scoop appears to be an exact copy of the 
original Shelby design.  Other than that......Maier's car is pretty stock 
looking and the change's he did make are both functional and in keeping 
with the original Shelby Trans Am car's.  This isn't a "rice burner" Honda 
Accord with a ridiculous whale tail, overdone ground effects and flames 
shooting out the tail pipe.
comments.author: James Jamieson

comments.text:
no its not, you fix and replace parts all the time why would you want to 
replace a part with an out of date one? if you want an old mustang youre 
probably going to drive it so why not make it the best driving experience 
possible, changing your your breaks and suspension changes just as much as 
the cosmetic stuff its not all about looks its about functionality

Cars were meant to be driven, cars back in the day drove like shit. what 
this guy is doing is actually beautiful because it updates the old cars 
everybody loves and makes it driveable and not only driveable but something 
you would never want to get out of. you can spend lots of money making a 
car original or you can make the car driveable, id rather driveable and 
maintaining and being proud of what is being done to do whatever it is 
which makes the car suit you, he kept the car extremely clean and really 
brought out the car it should be
comments.author: 530pm

comments.text:
I've owned classic Mustangs for over 30 years and here's the 
problem......before the restomod revolution....anything you did to change 
or alter the original design was considered a negative and lowered the 
overall value of the car plus...they handled like shit.  So ....there were 
thousands of rust buckets out there that you weren't supposed to change or 
modify and if you did....any $ you sunk into  your restoration that wasn't 
stock would be unrecoverable and therefore, not cost effective.  And they 
still handled like shit when you were done including shitty brakes and 
meager horse power by today standards.  People finally decided to break the 
mold and just make the cars they way they wanted and enough people with 
like minds joined in.  Now.....modified cars get the money back out 
(depending how far you go) and you now can get paid for the improvements 
when you go sell your car....Plus....there are now lots more of these cars 
being resurrected from the grave instead of going into the scrap yard.  You 
can still keep things concourse if you choose but there is now another 
option.  I think this is a very good thing in the big picture.
comments.author: James Jamieson
